Emotional support animals, therapy animals, and companion animals are not permitted in training classes, except in cases where such animals have been explicitly approved by your supervisor or home department as an accommodation. Individuals who are attending training classes who are allergic to, or have concerns about, service or therapy animals are encouraged to notify the office hosting your selected training in advance of the training to ensure adequate space is provided to mitigate contact with such animals. Accommodations The University of South Carolina is committed to providing access to all individuals attending training courses. If you require any specific accommodations as a result of a disability, please contact the instructor or unit delivering the training. Center for Teaching Excellence (CTE): cte@sc.edu Office of Access and Opportunity: ODEI@mailbox.sc.edu Office of Organizational and Professional Development (OPD): hrtrain@mailbox.sc.edu Training FAQs Expand all Do I need a USC email to register? No, you may use a personal email address. You can continue to use your personal email or change it later by admin request. Can my supervisor register me for a course using their account? No, each employee must create their own account to register. Employees self-register for all training courses with supervisor approval. Challenge the conventional.', 'Registration and Enrollment This course is 100% online.', "Frequently Asked Questions - Online Courses | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Online Courses SC.edu Study Online Courses Frequently Asked Questions Frequently Asked Questions We’ve compiled a list of the questions we get asked the most often. Courses Expand all Is a course I'm interested in provided online? You can search for distributed learning courses using our website(https://sc.edu/study/academic_overview/online_education/courses/course_search/index.php) or through the Self Services Carolina (SSC) Program(https://ssb.onecarolina.sc.edu) . Some courses may have restrictions (i.e., enrollment capacity, field of study, campus, etc.) placed on them by the departments, colleges/schools and/or campuses. How do I enroll in an online course? Current students: Log in to https://my.sc.edu(https://my.sc.edu/) and sign in to the Self Services Carolina (SSC) Program(https://ssb.onecarolina.sc.edu) to register. Non-USC students: Apply for admission depending on your circumstances (e.g., degree-seeking or non-degree seeking) and the level of the course or program of study in which you are interested. For additional information about admission requirements, visit the Undergraduate Admissions Office or the Graduate School(http://www.gradschool.sc.edu/) websites. How do I register for an online course if it has a restriction? You may contact the department offering the course to request an override to enroll in the course. Override requests are handled by the departments within the college/school offering the course and require their approval. What is the cost of an online course? Tuition and fees vary depending on total course hours, college/school or department offering the course, your residency status, and college campus. Tuition and fee information(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/bursar/tuition_and_required_fees/index.php) is available on the Bursar’s Office website. Can I get a copy of the syllabus before I enroll? Instructors who use Blackboard may post the course syllabus prior to the start of the semester. If you require a syllabus prior to registering for the course, you may want to contact the instructor. How do I access the online course after registering? If your course is taught using Blackboard, you will be able to access the course online through that Learning Management System. Instructors using other course delivery formats will send you instructions to access the course. Make sure you check your USC email account. Where do I find textbook information for my online course? Required textbook information is provided in the syllabus which may be posted in the course information in Blackboard prior to the start of the course. Are USC Columbia's online courses self-paced or schedule-based? Course formats vary. Some instructors choose to have a structured schedule with deadlines to be met along with required online course sessions or in-person events (such as an orientation, seminars, etc.). Other instructors choose not to have specific deadlines and allow students to access course materials and complete assignments at their discretion. It is important for you to read the syllabus carefully for this information and check your USC email account regularly. Courses must begin and end on the course dates as assigned according to the term in which the course is offered. These dates will be posted in the Self Services Carolina Program. Immunization Requirements Expand all Do online students have to provide immunization records? Online students must provide immunization records or complete the Distant Learner Waiver. Visit sc.edu/myhealthspace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/) to complete any immunization requirements or complete the Distant Learner Waiver. To complete the waiver: Log into https://sc.edu/myhealthspace(https://sc.edu/myhealthspace) Select Downloadable Forms (left side of the screen) Click on the Download button for your applicable form Fill out the form and save to your device Click on Upload Upload the document Click Save at the bottom of the page Note that this waiver must be submitted each semester of enrollment. If you do not provide immunization records or submit the waiver each semester, you will receive an immunization hold and will be unable to register for courses. For help with an immunization hold, please contact Student Health Services at 803-777-3175. Library Expand all How do I access the library’s online resources?"]
response:
To access the online course after registering, follow these steps:

1. Log in to the Self Services Carolina (SSC) Program at https://ssb.onecarolina.sc.edu using your credentials.
2. Navigate to the course you have registered for in the SSC Program.
3. Follow the instructions provided in the course description or syllabus to access the online course content. Most likely, it will be hosted on Blackboard, but some instructors might use other platforms.
4. Make sure to check your USC email account regularly for any updates or announcements from your instructor.
reference: If your course is taught using Blackboard,you will be able to access the course online through that Learning Management System. Instructors using other course delivery formats will send you instructions to access the course. Make sure you check your USC email account.

user_input: Where do I find textbook information for my online course?
retrieved_contexts: ["There's no one answer for everyone, but you can use a mix of Open Educational Resources, library-licensed resources, and items freely available or in the public domain on the web. Don't get discouraged if you do not immediately see an open textbook that fits your needs. A librarian can help you locate alternate resources to make your class affordable. Using OER Using Open Educational Resources (OER) is one way to make your class affordable. Most OER are funded by governments, foundation grants, or universities and are created, edited, and peer-reviewed by academics, ensuring that their quality is comparable to traditional textbooks. While many OER are created for lower level, high-enrollment courses, more are being developed for higher-level specialized courses. To locate OER to use in your classes, visit http://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/opentextbooks(http://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/opentextbooks) . Using Library-Licensed Resources While library-licensed resources are not OER and may come with copyright and licensing restrictions, using materials available through your library can save your students money. The library offers e-books, databases, and journals that can be easily linked to and freely accessed through Blackboard or your syllabus. Course Materials Support The library will scan library materials or find links to resources for you at no cost in Blackboard. We will also address copyright concerns connected to posting these materials. To provide this service, we need a list of the reading assignments as well as the dates of the assignments. Course Materials Support(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/find_services/faculty_services/course_materials/index.php) Send your syllabus to request links in Blackboard for articles, streaming videos, book chapters, and ebooks. SCoer Faculty Awards Check the SCoer website(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/find_services/faculty_services/course_materials/scoer/index.php) for information on upcoming SCoer Awards. 2024 SCoer Winners(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/exhibits_events_news/news/2024/scoer_winners_24.php) Learn about the 2024 SCoer winners. 2023 SCoer Winners(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/exhibits_events_news/news/2023/scoer_winners_23.php) Learn about the 2023 SCoer winners. 2022 SCoer Winners(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/exhibits_events_news/news/2022/scoer_2022.php) Learn about the 2022 SCoer winners. 2021 SCoer Winners(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/exhibits_events_news/news/2021/scoer_2021.php) Learn about the 2021 SCoer winners. 2020 SCoer Winners(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/exhibits_events_news/news/scoer2020.php) Learn about the 2020 SCoer winners. 2019 SCoer Winners(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/exhibits_events_news/news/scoer_2019.php) Learn about the 2019 SCoer winners. 2018 SCoer Winners(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/exhibits_events_news/news/2018/scoer_2018.php) Learn about the 2018 SCoer winners. Statewide Initiatives Learn about statewide initiatives(http://pascalsc.libguides.com/scale/faculty) to help you adopt affordable resources offered by the Partnership Among South Carolina Academic Libraries (PASCAL). PASCAL is currently accepting applications for the Professors for Affordable Learning Award(https://pascalsc.libguides.com/scale/faculty/pal) . Learn more from the PASCAL website(http://pascalsc.libguides.com/scale/faculty) . Get Help!", 'Open Textbooks - Open Educational Resources - Library Guides at University of South Carolina Skip to Main Content Search this Guide Search Open Educational Resources Home(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/OpenEducationalResources) Make Your Class Affordable(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/affordableclass) Open Textbooks(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/opentextbooks) Open Textbooks Search Across OER Sources Open Textbooks(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/textbooks) Evaluating Content(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/evaluate) Open Pedagogy(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/pedagogy) Open Case Studies(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/casestudies) Create Your Own OER(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/createOER) Open Textbooks Top collections Open Textbook Library(https://open.umn.edu/opentextbooks/) A curated catalog of open textbooks, meant to be a tool for instructors. This catalog includes and accepts reviews from faculty members.', 'Open Textbooks - Open Educational Resources - Library Guides at University of South Carolina Skip to Main Content Search this Guide Search Open Educational Resources Home(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/OpenEducationalResources) Make Your Class Affordable(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/affordableclass) Open Textbooks(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/opentextbooks) Open Textbooks(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/textbooks) Open Textbooks Search Across OER Sources Evaluating Content(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/evaluate) Open Pedagogy(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/pedagogy) Open Case Studies(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/casestudies) Create Your Own OER(https://guides.library.sc.edu/OER/createOER) Open Textbooks Top collections Open Textbook Library(https://open.umn.edu/opentextbooks/) A curated catalog of open textbooks, meant to be a tool for instructors. This catalog includes and accepts reviews from faculty members.']
response:
To find textbook information for your online course, first check if there's a designated section in the course management system where the textbook details are provided. If not, you can usually find this information on the university's bookstore website, such as the Barnes & Noble @ USC Bookstore. You can search for your course materials by selecting the term, department, and course number. Keep in mind that some instructors might choose alternative textbooks or openly accessible resources, so it's essential to double-check the syllabus or contact the instructor for confirmation.

Regarding music, since the context doesn't provide specific information about it, I cannot directly relate it to finding textbook information. However, if you're looking for open educational resources (OER) related to music or music education, there are various sources available online. Some popular platforms include the Open Music Theory Textbook, Musopen, and the Internet Archive's Live Music Archive. These resources offer free and open access to music-related content, which could potentially be used as supplementary materials for your online course.
reference: Required textbook information is provided in the syllabus which may be posted in the course information in Blackboard prior to the start of the course.Are USC Columbia's online courses self-paced or schedule-based?Course formats vary. Some instructors choose to have a structured schedule with deadlines to be met along with required online course sessions or in-person events (such as an orientation,seminars,etc.).  Other instructors choose not to have specific deadlines and allow students to access course materials and complete assignments at their discretion.  It is important for you to read the syllabus carefully for this information and check your USC email account regularly. Courses must begin and end on the course dates as assigned according to the term in which the course is offered. These dates will be posted in the Self Services Carolina Program.

user_input: Do online students have to provide immunization records?
retrieved_contexts: ['Submit Your Immunization Records & TB Test - International Student and Scholar Support | University of South Carolina Skip to Content International Student and Scholar Support SC.edu About Offices and Divisions International Student and Scholar Support New Student Arrival Submit Your Immunization Records Submit Your Immunization Records & TB Test Just like getting an I-20 and attending orientation, providing required immunization records is one of the steps you must complete before you can take classes at USC. Make sure you are prepared for this before you arrive on campus! What you need to know If you will live on campus(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/housing/index.php) , you must submit your immunization records to move in to your residence hall. All students , regardless of where you will live, must submit their immunization records to register for classes. If you are concerned that you will not be able to complete the immunization requirements before you arrive on campus, don\'t worry! University Health Services(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/health_services/) will allow you to take care of your immunizations once you arrive at USC. If you decide to get your immunizations done at USC, make sure that your health insurance is active before getting the immunizations done. What you need to do Navigate to the "Medical Clearances" portion of sc.edu/myhealthspace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/login_directory.aspx) . Click on "Immunizations Record" and attach supporting documentation signed by a medical provider before orientation. (Note: You can take a photo of your documentation with your phone and upload the photo). Enter your immunization dates and vaccine types in the "Medical Clearances" portion for each vaccine received. You can read more about required immunizations on the University Health Services website(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student-health-well-being/medical-services/immunizations/index.php) . Note that if you are from a country that is considered "high burden" for tuberculosis, you will need to complete a TB test and chest x-ray upon arrival to the U.S. Immunization Hold A registration hold(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/student_advising_resources/registration_holds/index.php) is on your account until your vaccination records are updated. Student Health and Well-Being\'s Immunization Office lifts these holds. University Health Services: Center for Health & Well-Being Immunization Office Phone : 803-777-9511 Fax : 803-777-3955 First Floor(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student-health-well-being/about/location/index.php) Room 104 1401 Devine St. Columbia, SC 29208 Hours Monday-Friday 8:30 a.m.', 'Clearing Immunization Holds - Academic Advising | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Academic Advising SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Academic Advising Student Advising Resources Registration Holds Clearing Immunization Holds Clearing Immunization Holds The University of South Carolina (USC) immunization requirements are consistent with the recommendations of the American College Health Association and the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. Compliance with all immunization, post screening tests, treatment regimens, and monitoring is Mandatory. Students not fulfilling the immunization requirements, with exceptions for valid medical contraindications or documented religious reasons, will not be permitted to register for or drop classes. Expand all Which immunizations are required? Student Health Services lists required immunizations on the Immunizations website. When are immunizations holds placed on students accounts? All students enrolled at USC will initially have an immunization hold on their account. The hold is removed when students are marked "Compliant" for required vaccines and the TB Screen Risk Form. How do students obtain a copy of their immunization records? Transfer students will need to request their immunization records from their previous school. Please note, SHS is not able to request records on behalf of the student. Students can contact their high school or primary health provider or pediatrician. SC residents can contact DHEC. Residents from other states, can contact their local health department. How do students enter vaccine information? Students will log into sc.edu/MyHealthSpace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/login_dualauthentication.aspx) . Click on Medical Clearances from the menu Click on Update to enter the immunization information Students will enter the name of the vaccine and the date(s) received and then click on done. If the student chooses the incorrect vaccine, the staff at SHS can correct it. How do students upload immunization records? Students will need to upload a copy of their immunization record. This is required in order for SHS staff to verify the vaccines/dates entered by the student are correct. After the student clicks ‘update’ next to immunization record, a box will open with an option to upload documents. What happens when requirements are met? Once the student has provided the necessary records, or signed the distance learner form (for on-line students only & must be completed each semester) their name will appear on an immunization clearance list. Immunizations staff update the student\'s records and the immunizations hold is lifted in Self Service Carolina at midnight. Are there exemptions? You can only be exempt from fulfilling immunization requirements if: You have a permanent medical contraindication. You have conflicting religious beliefs.', "All incoming students receive an email from Student Health Services 45 days before the start of classes that outlines the pre-matriculation requirements. These must be completed prior to attending classes and/or clinical rotations. A deadline is included for completion of these requirements, typically two to three weeks before the start of classes. This includes submitting verifiable documentation of immunization or immunity (quantitative antibody titers) to specified infectious conditions. Students who fail to complete forms and submit documentation will not be allowed to attend classes and/or clinicals. Click here(https://musc.policytech.com/dotNet/documents/?docid=5737&public=true ) to review the Student Vaccine Policy. If you have questions or concerns regarding immunization requirements please email to shsimmunizations@musc.edu or call 843-792-3664 to speak with a member of the Student Health Clinic. Admissions University Admissions, part of Enrollment Management, provides centralized services for prospective and current applicants, and all contact between applicants and MUSC should originate with this office. University Admissions makes all application forms accessible online, and staff are available to assist you in understanding prerequisite requirements, transcript submission, and additional application processes. Decisions regarding eligibility for admission and offers of admission are made solely through each College. However, all contact between applicants and MUSC should originate with Enrollment Management. Factors considered by programs in their admission decisions include the applicant's previous academic success, work previously completed, and cognitive and non-cognitive traits necessary and desirable in health professionals, health administrators, and/or biomedical scientists (e.g., leadership, compassion, teamwork, creativity, curiosity). MUSC values diversity among its applicants and in its student body. MUSC does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, creed, sex, age, national origin, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, veteran status, or marital status in the administration of admission policies, educational policies, financial aid, or any other university activity. Any applicant needing assistance during any stage of the admission process is invited to contact the University Office of Admissions at oesadmis@musc.edu . Application filing deadlines vary by program. Information Privacy MUSC seeks to protect your personal information and complies with applicable state and federal regulations. Only authorized MUSC employees and officials acting on behalf of the university have access to materials submitted in support of your application to enroll at the university. Consideration for Admission To be reviewed and considered for admission, all applicants must file their application with a non-refundable processing fee. All materials submitted in support of the admission process become the exclusive property of MUSC and cannot be returned to the student or duplicated for any purpose. These materials usually include, but are not limited to, official transcripts of all prior graduate and undergraduate work, letters of recommendation, and national test scores. Applicants are only considered for the semester and the program they specify on the application form. Changes require an applicant to refile an application and to pay an additional filing fee. Deferrals in the anticipated enrollment date requested after acceptance of the admission offer are made only with the approval of the program involved. The accepted applicant must complete the applicant response form and pay the matriculation fee to hold their place in the program as well as meet any conditions of their acceptance. Academic preparation (in the form of transfer credits, diplomas, or degrees) required for entrance into any of the programs at MUSC must ordinarily have been earned at an institution accreditation by an organization recognized by the Department of Education. The admissions committee of a particular college at MUSC may consider an applicant from a non-accredited institution in competition with other applicants if it determines that the applicant’s academic preparation meets the entrance requirements of the college. In addition, the committee on admissions of the respective MUSC college may require a recognized examination such as the Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT), the American College Test (ACT), the Medical College Admission Test (MCAT), the Graduate Record Examination (GRE), the Dental Admission Test (DAT), the Pharmacy College Admission Test (PCAT), the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), and recognized national professional board examinations. Credit by examination is allowed on a limited basis.", 'Immunizations - Student Health and Well-Being | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Student Health and Well-Being SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Student Health and Well-Being Medical Services Immunizations Immunizations You have access to a full range of vaccines offered by Student Health, including those required by the university. Call 803-777-9511. Help Fight the Flu Protect yourself this season by receiving your Flu vaccine. Student Health is administering the Flu vaccine in the Center for Health and Well-Being. A limited supply of vaccines are available on a first come, first serve basis. Anyone interested in getting the vaccination can make an appointment(https://nam02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fmyhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu%2Flogin_dualauthentication.aspx&data=05%7C01%7CDH43%40mailbox.sc.edu%7Cdbe8875a1b7641562d1c08dbbeb6e157%7C4b2a4b19d135420e8bb2b1cd238998cc%7C0%7C0%7C638313464910808389%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=r1eSdMlqcTBFl0EwJLVjokV8sjoNXW56ZsJrpxV4dAU%3D&reserved=0) . The vaccine is available to students, faculty and staff at no cost as long as you upload your insurance card to MyHealthSpace(https://nam02.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fsc.us3.list-manage.com%2Ftrack%2Fclick%3Fu%3De551513d7b7cf084b5203a513%26id%3D646e07942c%26e%3D29b9d8e891&data=05%7C01%7CDH43%40mailbox.sc.edu%7Cdbe8875a1b7641562d1c08dbbeb6e157%7C4b2a4b19d135420e8bb2b1cd238998cc%7C0%7C0%7C638313464910808389%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=w7nu4XKLBr%2FFGyg4hs4Ezue0Dwy2AvpkL4C2kTGunl4%3D&reserved=0) . If insurance cards are not uploaded or you have Medicare, a $40 charge will be posted to your Bursar accounts. Medicare members will need to file with Medicare to be reimbursed. Alternate locations to receive the Flu vaccine are at your local CVS, Walgreens, Health Department, or your Primary Care Physicians\' office. Please call either location to ensure that they are currently offering the vaccine and to inquire about out-of-pocket cost. Required Immunizations Expand all MMR Vaccine (2 Doses) You\'ll need two doses of the measles, mumps and rubella vaccine (MMR), or positive blood titer reports. Please record these in the "Medical Clearances" section on myhealthspace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/login_dualauthentication.aspx) Meningococcal Vaccine (MENVEO or Menactra) You\'ll need the meningococcal vaccine to prevent meningitis if you are younger than 21. You must have received at least one meningococcal vaccine after your 16th birthday to satisfy this requirement. Please record these in the "Medical Clearances" section on myhealthspace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/login_dualauthentication.aspx) TB Risk Screening Complete the questionnaire found in the "Medical Clearances" section on myhealthspace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/login_dualauthentication.aspx) If needed, you will be prompted to have tuberculosis testing after answering the TB Screening Questions. Exemptions You can only be exempt from fulfilling immunization requirements if: You have a permanent medical contraindication. You have conflicting religious beliefs. You are enrolled in only distance education courses. You will need to provide proof of your exemption status. Recommended Immunizations We recommend all students get these preventive vaccines for their overall health and well-being. Gardasil (all students younger than 26) Hepatitis A & B Varicella (chicken pox) Tetanus/Diphtheria/Pertussis (Tdap) Meningococcal Group B The SARS-CoV2 Vaccine is highly recommended. If you need a copy of your immunizations please log into your myhealthspace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/login_dualauthentication.aspx) account to view and print your immunizations or call 803-777-2870. Allergy and Immunization Phone: 803-777-9511 Fax: 803-777-3955 Center for Health and Well-Being Third Floor 1401 Devine St. Columbia, SC 29208 Hours Monday-Friday 8:30 a.m.']
response: Online students are not required to submit immunization records unless they plan to visit the campus for any reason. It is essential to comply with immunization requirements if they intend to take advantage of on-campus resources or activities. Otherwise, online students can complete their studies without submitting immunization records.
reference: Online students must provide immunization records or complete the Distant Learner Waiver. Visit sc.edu/myhealthspace to complete any immunization requirements or complete the Distant Learner Waiver. To complete the waiver: Log into https://sc.edu/myhealthspaceSelect Downloadable Forms (left side of the screen)Click on the Download button for your applicable formFill out the form and save to your deviceClick on UploadUpload the documentClick Save at the bottom of the pageNote that this waiver must be submitted each semester of enrollment. If you do not provide immunization records or submit the waiver each semester,you will receive an immunization hold and will be unable to register for courses. For help with an immunization hold,please contact Student Health Services at 803-777-3175.

user_input: How do I access the library’s online resources?
retrieved_contexts: ["Online Resources @ USC - Accessing & Discovering Online Resources - Library Guides at University of South Carolina Skip to Main Content Search this Guide Search Accessing & Discovering Online Resources Online Resources @ USC(https://guides.library.sc.edu/c.php?g=410273&p=2794245) Online Resources Search Options Off-Campus Access Find Databases(https://guides.library.sc.edu/access-and-discovery/databases) Get the Full Text of an Article(https://guides.library.sc.edu/access-and-discovery/full-text) Find Online Journals(https://guides.library.sc.edu/access-and-discovery/journals) Ebook HelpThis link opens in a new window(http://guides.library.sc.edu/ebook-help) Reporting Problems(https://guides.library.sc.edu/access-and-discovery/problems) Online Resources University Libraries provides access to a wide array of online resources, including searchable databases, online journal subscriptions, ebooks, streaming videos, and more. Learn more about the different ways you can search, discover and access online resources from the library. Search Options Whether you're just starting to discover resources on your topic or you need a particular article, the search tools below can help. Find It @ USC – The default is a broad search across multiple resources for Articles, Books, and More Choose to narrow your search to only USC Libraries catalog or the PASCAL Delivers catalog Databases – Choose to search a specialized database in a particular subject area or by content type Journals – Search by the journal, magazine or newspaper title to learn what online and print access the library provides Search the Libraries(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/search/index.php) When you're ready, return to the library website to start searching! Off-Campus Access Use your network username and password to login to the library's online resources from off campus.", "How do I access a specific library database? - FAQ Skip to Main Content University Libraries(http://sc.edu/libraries) FAQ Warning: Your browser has javascript disabled. Without javascript some functions will not work, including question submission via the form. Q. How do I access a specific library database? Toggle menu visibility Search 0 options available. Use up and down arrows to browse available options and enter to select one. Ask Browse: All Groups Default South Caroliniana Topics 26 About the Libraries 22 Borrowing Stuff 9 Campus Services 10 Featured 35 Finding Stuff 5 Proxy 21 Research Help 18 Technology 13 Where in the Library... Answered By: Research Help, Thomas Cooper Library Last Updated: Oct 06, 2022 Views: 1022 You can find a complete list of the library's subscription databases with links for access from our website by clicking on Databases at the bottom of the main search box on the homepage or using the link below. If needed, you will be prompted to login with your Network username and password. If you are looking for access to a specific publication, such as a particular journal, newspaper, or magazine, the best strategy is to click on Journals (next to the link for databases on the homepage) and search by the publication title to learn what resource(s) provide access. Links & Files A-Z Databases(http://guides.library.sc.edu/az.php) My username and password are not working. What should I do?(http://libanswers.library.sc.edu/faq/231891) Journals (by publication title)(https://pascal-usc.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/jsearch?vid=01PASCAL_USCCOL:USC) Toggle action bar FAQ Actions Print Tweet Share on Facebook Was this helpful? Yes 0 No 1 Comments (0) Add a public comment to this FAQ Entry Search again Search 0 options available.", "Stacy Winchester is a research data librarian in University Libraries’ digital research services department at the University of South Carolina. We asked her about resources for parents during this period of at-home learning. With the closing of K-12 schools across the state, parents are now more involved than ever in their children's education. What online resources are available through University Libraries that could support their efforts? The University Libraries at UofSC provide access to over 400 research databases(http://guides.library.sc.edu/az.php?a=all) . This huge collection of materials is available from home and covers every discipline and topic imaginable. In addition to the libraries’ regular online collections, some companies are also making access to their educational content free to facilitate learning from home during this period of uncertainty. Kathy Snediker, Research and Instruction Librarian at Thomas Cooper Library, has created an online guide(https://guides.library.sc.edu/library-support-covid/free-stuff) that highlights content recently made free. More information will be added to this guide as it becomes available. Does University Libraries have resources for all K-12 students, even the early elementary grades? The University Libraries provide access to many online K-12 resources.(http://guides.library.sc.edu/az.php?a=all&t=31489) These include quality educational materials suitable for elementary through high school grade levels. Students can use these resources to access narrated picture books and graphic novels, primary source materials, periodical content, reference materials at a variety of grade levels, and more. What tips would you offer to parents who want to nurture their children's sense of curiosity and tap into their digital native abilities to find information online? Most children know how to access information online, but they don’t always understand how to differentiate quality sources of information from those they should not trust. This problem may be amplified because children often get their news from social media(https://eric.ed.gov/?id=EJ1190639) . There’s a huge amount of misinformation online, and in the search for answers to their questions about COVID-19, for example, they may stumble upon inaccurate information. Parents can help steer their children toward quality sources of information. Library content is a great place to start. Parents can ask their children questions about the sources they choose when seeking information. Can the child tell who is responsible for content they find online and how old the content is? Why is the information being made available? Is it purely informational or are the content creators trying to sell a product? Are there any clues on the website about whether the content creators might be good sources of information on the topic? If children have questions about the accuracy of information they find online, pointing them toward objective, fact-checking sites such as Snopes(http://snopes.com) and Politifact(https://www.politifact.com/) can empower them to make determinations themselves. In addition to the resources offered above, the university's South Carolina Center for Community Literacy has assembled an online resource guide(https://sites.google.com/view/scccl-resources-covid19/home) for parents and teachers.", "If you're only interested in online materials , you can select Available Online under Availability on the left. Or, if you're only interested in physical books at the law library , you can filter your search results by Library on the left. Finding After you have run a search in the library catalog(http://law.sc.edu/library) , you will see a list of search results . You can click on a title in the results list to see details about that book. Click on Available Online below the title of an ebook or article in an online journal. Then a direct link will appear, and you can login with your USC login to access the text. Ask at the Reference desk how to find a physical book using a call number , such as KF1250 .J64 2009. Sign in with your USC login to see more ways to request a book . The Request link only appears after you have clicked on a title to get details and you have signed in. For example, by clicking Request, you can place a hold on a checked-out book. A librarian will email you when the book is available. As another example, you can Request to borrow books from other libraries in the USC system. Their books and ours are all searchable together in the same library catalog. If possible, the book you request will be made available for you to pickup and return at the law library's Circulation desk . Checking Out You can check out and check in borrowed materials at the law library's Circulation desk . Your Carolina Card (law student ID) is your library card . How long something can be checked out(https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/law/law_library/services/students.php) varies by the type of material. <<Previous:What's in the Library for You(https://guides.law.sc.edu/LRAWFall/InTheLibrary) Next:Course Objectives >>(https://guides.law.sc.edu/LRAWFall/Objectives) Last Updated: Sep 20, 2024 5:48 PM URL: https://guides.law.sc.edu/LRAWFall Print Page Login to LibApps(https://law-sc.libapps.com/libapps/login.php?site_id=5549&target64=L2xpYmd1aWRlcy9hZG1pbl9jLnBocD9nPTMxNTUzOSZwPTk3MzMwODg=) Report a problem Subjects: Law School(https://guides.law.sc.edu/sb.php?subject_id=82511)", 'Access From Off-Campus - Get Online Access & Avoid Paywalls - Library Guides at University of California, Santa Cruz Skip to Main Content University Library Search Get Online Access & Avoid Paywalls Access From Off-Campus(https://guides.library.ucsc.edu/get-online-access/off-campus) Nomad Browser Extension(https://guides.library.ucsc.edu/get-online-access/nomad) Google Scholar(https://guides.library.ucsc.edu/get-online-access/google-scholar) Proxy Errors & Permalinks(https://guides.library.ucsc.edu/get-online-access/proxy) Get Library Access From Off-Campus When you’re off campus, online books and articles don’t know that you are a UCSC student or faculty member eligible to access those materials. Quick options for getting access when you’re off campus: Option 1: Start your research from UC Library Search(https://ucsc.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/search?vid=01CDL_SCR_INST:USCS&lang=en) Option 2: Log in to Online Access(https://my.openathens.net/auth?entityID=https%3A%2F%2Fidp.ucsc.edu%2Fentity) Nomad Browser Extension for Quick Access Download the Nomad browser extension to get quick access to online articles and books! Nomad will tell you if you have access through the UCSC Library and provide a link where you can log in to get the full-text. Get Nomad(https://thirdiron.com/downloadnomad/) Get Help With Access Hit a paywall? Broken links?']
response: To access the University Libraries' online resources, including searchable databases, online journal subscriptions, ebooks, and streaming videos, visit the Online Resources page on the University Libraries' website. Here, you can explore various search options, off-campus access methods, and reporting procedures for any issues encountered while accessing these resources.
reference: Students can start at the library’s homepage to access subscription databases,online journals and ebooks away from campus using their network username and password. Learn more about Off-Campus Access to library resources,including book delivery and scans of print materials. Check out this online guide to accessing and discovering online resources for help getting started.

user_input: How can I get help with doing research?
retrieved_contexts: ["How should I go about it? We encourage students interested in research to contact faculty directly. Send them an email or drop by their office. You can learn about each person's research area by looking at their personal page or lab page. You can view the list of all our department faculty . If you click on a person's name you will eventually reach their personal page with all their research interests. If you think you might be interested in doing research in those topics then contact that person.", 'Below you will find information and resources designed to help you start the process. Enjoy our Getting Started in Research video and schedule an individual consultation to learn more about your next steps. Ready to Get Started? Let us help! Expand all Resources and tips for discovering your research interests and a mentor These worksheets are used in individual consultations and can help you clarify your research interests and also outline the research journey - start to finish. What are your research interests? The research journey : How to get involved, find a faculty mentor, and next steps. Tips and hints for emailing faculty about research opportunities Need an email signature? Check out the USC Email Signature Generator. Use our faculty research database(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_research/get-started/faculty_research_database/index.php) to identify faculty who have research interests similar to yours. Schedule a research consultation The Office of Undergraduate Research offers individual consultations where we will explore your research interests, walk through how to find and reach out to potential faculty mentors, and discuss next steps. To schedule a RESEARCH CONSULTATION(https://sc.campus.eab.com) *: Consultations will be offered for both in person and virtually. Virtual consultations will be facilitated through Teams video conferencing. A weblink will be provided to you in your meeting confirmation email. Please click on the weblink at your designated meeting time to start your appointment. Log on to sc.campus.eab.com(https://sc.campus.eab.com) Click on "Make an Appointment" tab (right hand side of the screen) Under what type of appointment, select "Involvement and Engagement" Under service, select "Undergraduate Research Appointment" Then click on the button "Find Available Time" Please feel free to include comments about where you are in the research journey (curious about research, ready to get started, have a mentor/questions about funding, etc.). This helps us better serve you! *If the appointment options conflict with your schedule , please contact us directly at our@sc.edu with days and times you are available to meet. Want to be the first to hear about new research opportunities? Connect with us!Follow us on Instagram and twitter, like us on facebook, and sign up for our newsletter to see the latest happenings in the OUR! We post research opportunities, stories about faculty and undergraduate researchers, and upcoming events and deadlines.(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_research/about-us/social_media.php) Researcher Rights, Responsibilities, and Resources Each campus has a document that provides guidance on your rights and responsibilities as well as some handy resources (research and academic). Aiken [pdf] Beaufort [pdf] Columbia [pdf] Lancaster [pdf] Salkehatchie [pdf] Sumter [pdf] Union [pdf] Upstate [pdf] NO forms of discrimination or harassment are tolerated at the University of South Carolina. Policies(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/civil_rights_title_ix/policies_and_procedures/index.php) and reporting of incidents(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/civil_rights_title_ix/reporting/index.php) are available through Office of Civil Rights & Title IX(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/civil_rights_title_ix/index.php) . NSF has also taken a firm stance against harassment and discrimination. For NSF funded projects, please see NSF.gov/harassment(https://www.nsf.gov/od/oecr/harassment.jsp) . Questions? Email us at our@sc.edu. We are here to help. Schedule a Presentation! Schedule a presentation(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_research/about-us/request-presentation/index.php) with our office! We\'d love to share with your class, organization, residence hall or any group open to our message that research is a great enrichment opportunity for undergraduate students in every discipline. We can answer questions like: What is research? What are the benefits of doing research? How do I get started? Where\'s the money? Contact Us Office of Undergraduate Research Legare College Suite 120 Columbia, SC 29208 Phone : 803-777-1141 Email: our@sc.edu Make An Appointment(https://sc.campus.eab.com/) Mail Address Legare College 120 Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional.', 'No project? No mentor? No problem! Step 1: Find a faculty research mentor - Let us help! We have options: Expand all What is a research mentor? The role of a mentor is to: assist in the development and articulation of a project idea and plan. help you understand the methods and concepts of research and scholarship within your field. guide and train you in the skills and/or techniques needed to complete a project. There is no pressure to come up with your own idea because most students work directly on a faculty project. Options for finding a research mentor Expand all View our Getting Started in Research Workshop Video Located in the Getting Started in Research Toolkit(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_research/get-started/getting_started_toolkit/index.php) , this video is designed to help students navigate the undergraduate research process. Resources and tips for finding your research interests and a mentor These worksheets are used in our Getting Started in Research Consultations and can help you clarify your research interests and also outline the research journey - start to finish. What are your research interests? The research journey : How to get involved, find a faculty mentor, and next steps. Tips and hints for emailing faculty about research opportunities Need an email signature? Check out the USC Email Signature Generator(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/communications/toolbox/resources/email_signature_generator/index.php) . Use our searchable research database(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_research/get-started/faculty_research_database/index.php) to identify faculty who have research interests similar to yours. Still have questions? Schedule a research consultation The Office of Undergraduate Research offers individual consultations where we will explore your research interests, walk through how to find and reach out to potential faculty mentors, and discuss next steps. To schedule a RESEARCH CONSULTATION* : Consultations will be held either in person or virtually through Teams video conferencing. If you select a virtual consultation, a weblink will be provided to you in your meeting confirmation email. Please click on the weblink at your designated meeting time to start your appointment. => Log on to sc.campus.eab.com => Click on "Make an Appointment" tab (right hand side of the screen) => Under what type of appointment, select "Involvement and Engagement" => Under service, select "Undergraduate Research Appointment" => Then click on the button "Find Available Time" Please feel free to include comments about where you are in the research journey (curious about research, ready to get started, have a mentor/questions about funding, etc.). This helps us better help you! * If these appointment options conflict with your schedule , please contact us directly at our@sc.edu with days and times you are available to meet by video. More options: Talk to your current or past professors after class, ask for a meeting, or stop by their office hours. Do they have opportunities for students or suggestions for other faculty who might? Ask peers about their professors or research mentors. Take a professor out-to-lunch with the Student Success Center’s Out-To-Lunch Program . Still have questions? Contact us Always feel free to contact us by email or phone (803-777-1141) as well - we are here to help at every step along your research journey! Step 2: Embark on your research journey Have a mentor and project? You\'re ready to move on to the next steps. Expand all Register Your Project Record your undergraduate research experience and enter your project(s) in the OUR Research Registry . This is required every semester for research to appear on your "My USC Experience" transcript. Working with a Mentor Tips, hints, and resources to make the most of your research experience with your mentor. Apply for Funding Find funding to support your research project, and get application deadlines and details. Share Your Work Publish, present, and get the word out about your research findings. Resources and Opportunities for Undergraduate Researchers Additional information and resources to help you along your research journey - from registering your project, to understanding your rights and responsibilities, to getting the most out of your research experiences by taking your work to the next level. Attend a Getting Started in Research Workshop! Led by OUR student advisors, this workshop guides students interested in engaging in research with the initial steps for becoming involved. Attendees will: Gain an understanding of their research interests Navigate the OUR Faculty Research Database to find potential mentors and learn how to communicate with them Begin developing a roadmap of what engaging in research can look like Fall 2024 Workshop offerings: Friday, September 27: 9:30-10:30 AM, Thomas Cooper Library Room L304 * 9/27 cancelled due to weather* Friday, October 11: 9:30-10:30 AM, Thomas Cooper Library Room L304 Friday, October 25: 9:30-10:30 AM, Thomas Cooper Library Room L304 Friday, November 8: 9:30-10:30 AM, Thomas Cooper Library Room L104 Why should you do research? What are the benefits?']
response:
The University of South Carolina (USC) offers various resources to help students with research. First, if you're interested in research, consider contacting faculty members directly via email or visiting their offices. You can learn about their research areas and determine if there's a match with your interests. You may use the faculty research database to find faculty members with similar research interests: <https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_research/get-started/faculty_research_database/index.php>.

Moreover, the Office of Undergraduate Research provides individual consultations to guide you through the process of starting research. They can help you clarify your research interests, find a faculty mentor, and discuss the next steps. To schedule a consultation, visit sc.campus.eab.com and follow the instructions provided in the context.

Lastly, you can attend a Getting Started in Research Workshop led by OUR student advisors. These workshops cover understanding research interests, navigating the OUR Faculty Research Database, and creating a roadmap for research engagement. Visit the following link to learn more about the workshop offerings: <https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_research/get-started/workshops/index.php>.
reference: Online help is available through live chat,virtual Book a Librarian research appointments,email,and online guides and tutorials. See all the ways you can get research help from the library.

user_input: Do I need to get a library card?
retrieved_contexts: ["“Sometimes that is what my job is,” she says. “It’s letting people feel free to say that does not exist in our community right now and to just be there with you while you're sad and try to help you figure out another way around it.” The services the library provides are unique because members of the community do not need a pre-existing reason to access its resources. If someone wants to see a social worker at their local hospital, they would need to be an admitted patient, but at the library, everyone is welcome. “You don't have to have a library card. You don't have to be a resident of Richland County,” says Patterson. “You just have to have a heartbeat to talk to us.”", '“You don’t even have to have a library card to talk to us. You don’t have to be a resident of Richland County. You just have to have a heartbeat.” Lee Patterson, MSW ’12 “They’ve given me a lot of freedom to say, ‘OK, this is the need that we’re seeing right now, and this is how we think we should approach it’ and the freedom to go forth and see how we can help,” says Patterson, MSW ’12. The San Francisco Public Library became the first library system to employ a full-time social worker in 2009. Since then, over 50 public libraries around the country have followed suit, including Richland Library, which was highlighted in an NPR piece on the emerging trend in 2022. The media attention was warranted, but the work is ongoing — and expanding. For example, Patterson and her team want to work with the American Heart Association to provide access to blood pressure cuffs. They are also exploring options for helping homeless people with diabetes and also hope to revive the flu shot clinics they offered in the past. The library also provides a degree of privacy. “You can walk into a library, and a person driving by would never know if you’re coming to get a book, use the bathroom or see a social worker,” Patterson explains. That can be important, she says, when people have had negative experiences trying to access health care in the past. “There’s perception and then there’s the reality that our clients can come with,” Patterson explains. “They worry they’ll be treated differently, and we’ve had clients who have been treated differently, even when they have health insurance. We’ve watched nurses or other practitioners treat them differently.” It’s a different story at the library, where anyone can access services without judgment and without being admitted as a patient. “You don’t even have to have a library card to talk to us. You don’t have to be a resident of Richland County,” says Patterson. “You just have to have a heartbeat.” Carolinian Magazine This article was originally published in Carolinian, the alumni magazine for the University of South Carolina. Meet more dynamic Carolinians and discover once again what makes our university great. View Carolinian(https://www.sc.edu/uofsc/carolinian/index.php)']
response: No, you don't need to get a library card to access the resources or talk to a social worker at Richland Library. As mentioned in the context, "You don’t even have to have a library card to talk to us. You don’t have to be a resident of Richland County." The library welcomes everyone, regardless of whether they have a library card or not.
reference: Your CarolinaCard is your library card,but you can still use the library if you have never been to campus to get a CarolinaCard. All enrolled students are set up with an online library account that you can use to request and renew materials,see due dates and pin favorite materials to personal lists. Your login is your network username and password. This is also the login to access library databases,online journals,and ebooks.

user_input: When are my tuition and fees due?
retrieved_contexts: ["Online tuition is due by 5 p.m. on published tuition deadline. If you are mailing a payment, it should be postmarked no later than 2 weeks prior to posted tuition deadline. The University of South Carolina's Federal School Code is 003448. Financial Aid We recommend that you begin thinking about your financial aid needs and options during the initial admissions process to University of South Carolina. Please contact our financial aid staff for assistance. Financial assistance may be available to you in the form of student loans. Students should allow up to 4-6 weeks for the financial aid process to be completed. If you have not received anticipated aid by the payment deadline, you are still responsible for paying for your course by the tuition deadline. Please plan accordingly. Notes* Expand all View Notes Full-time tuition is assessed per semester, unless otherwise noted [see note (11) below for exceptions]. Part-time tuition and fees are assessed per credit hour unless otherwise noted for students taking fewer than 12 credit hours per semester. Most Fees listed in the Full-Time columns are applicable to all students. Unless otherwise noted, all tuition and fees reviewed and approved by the USC Board of Trustees in June 2024 become effective in Fall 2024. USC Columbia - Chapter 33 veterans entitled to the maximum benefit rate (based on service requirements) who apply for the Yellow Ribbon Program at USC and are deemed eligible may receive a tuition abatement as follows for nonresident students: Undergraduate students - 50% of tuition and fee charges in excess of the VA maximum amounts for SC not to exceed $5,700 annually; Graduate/Professional students - 50% of tuition and fee charges in excess of the VA maximum amounts for SC not to exceed $3,400 annually. The number of eligible students is limited based upon the terms of the annual Yellow Ribbon Program Agreement. Qualified resident students are fully covered by the VA at the actual resident tuition rates. Free tuition per state law for: children of certain deceased and other veterans, firefighters and law enforcement officers, essay winner for Governor's Committee on the Employment of the Physically Handicapped, and resident 60 years or older on space available basis. Certain Veterans and related persons, residing in South Carolina, receiving specified Federal Educational Benefits and enrolled in a state institution are entitled to receive in-state tuition without regard to length of time the individual has resided in the state. See SC Code of Laws 59-112-50 as amended May 7, 2015. Columbia campus students receiving Academic Scholar – distinction award or an eligible Departmental Scholarship of at least $250 per semester. Columbia campus students named as McNair, Horseshoe Scholar, and Academic Scholar – Elite, Academic Scholar – Excellence, Academic Scholar – Superlative, Provost Scholar and Alumni Scholars. Nonresident Athletics scholarship implies athletic grant-in-aid at the USC Columbia Campus. This rate may not apply to all scholarship student-athletes, based upon designation by the Athletics Department. The Office of Student Financial Aid and Scholarships awards grants-in-aid in accordance with NCAA, and institutional guidelines. Columbia campus students receiving Academic Scholar – Merit Award. Active Duty Military - This is applied across USC System Institutions. Nonresident Active Duty Military pay the resident rate for distance courses. Applies to Undergraduates only. Applies to contracted ROTC students. Full-time Undergraduate students on Columbia, Aiken, Beaufort and Upstate campuses and all full-time Graduate students will pay an additional charge for each credit hour above sixteen hours. Nonrefundable after the 100% refund period. Graduate rates listed under USC Columbia apply to all campuses. USC Aiken has a program rate for Master of Business Administration – online program listed under campus rates. All other fees for Comprehensive and Palmetto College campuses are for undergraduate students only. Rate applies only to those specific on-line Graduate programs and courses as approved and identified by the Office of the Provost for Columbia or by the Office of the Chancellor at the comprehensive institutions. See Columbia Specially Priced Online Degree Programs: https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/bursar/tuition_and_required_fees/index.php(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/bursar/tuition_and_required_fees/index.php) USC Columbia - Undergraduate application fee waived only for domestic students who present a valid College Board, ACT, NACAC, Coalition, or Common App application fee waiver; who are dependents of current USC-Columbia faculty or staff; or who are military students applying for 2-year military associate’s degree at Fort Jackson. Graduate school application fees are retained by the General Fund, except for the $50 Moore School of Business additional amount. Additional graduate application fee waivers may be granted at the discretion of the Graduate School. The Study Abroad Exchange Program Deposit applied to tuition and fees in the semester in which the study abroad exchange program occurs. The deposit is non-refundable after payment is received. The Gamecock Gateway program is a partnership between the University of South Carolina Columbia (USC) and Midlands Technical College (MTC) to provide an academic and residential link between the two institutions. The Gamecock Gateway program is offered by invitation only and offers a residential experience on or near the USC campus. Students will pursue transfer compliant course work at MTC, while benefitting from a variety of support programs and student services offered by each institution. Upon successful completion of the one-year academic program in Gamecock Gateway, students will be eligible to fully matriculate at USC. The deposit is non-refundable. The matriculation fee is paid only once by undergraduate degree-seeking students during their entering semester through the campus where they initially enroll. The fee will be charged again if a student enrolls in a masters or doctoral program of study. For the USC Columbia campus, a portion of the fee is allocated to Arts & Sciences for new student placement testing. Capstone Scholar fee is payable in student's first and second year of the program. The optional athletic event fee includes per semester athletics activity charge and the athletics bond charge. For the student to elect the fee, the undergraduate student is required to have a minimum of six credit hours and graduate student is required to have one credit hour. Students participating in university-approved internships, practicums, co-ops or z-status as part of their academic program of study are eligible to pay the optional athletic fee during the semester of participation as long as they meet the one-credit hour minimum. Insurance charge as required for undergraduate students (6 hours or more), graduate students (9 hours or more), graduate assistants, and international students; proof of insurance is required to be eligible for the exemption of this coverage. Other students, not required to provide proof of insurance, may opt into the third-party program. Mandatory Study Abroad Insurance is based on a $360 academic year rate (or current contract, whichever is greater) that is pro-rated for length of time the student spends abroad. Dual Enrollment Courses - USC Columbia, USC Aiken, USC Beaufort and USC Upstate may waive the dual enrollment charge or charge less than the $66 per credit hour rate with 4% fee waiver capacity for resident students. This rate applies to full and part time students regardless of status. The $66 per credit hour rate is a minimum. The course charge may not exceed the resident credit hour tuition for each USC Campus. Reinstatement Fee is assessed to students who have been dropped from their classes due to nonpayment and wish to be re-enrolled in classes for the same term. This fee is assessed per occurrence. Certified Teacher Rate is $515.00 for resident students per hour for the Columbia campuses. This rate is a 10% reduction to the regular resident graduate rate. The rate is $620.00 for nonresident students per hour for the Columbia campus (50% of Nonresident Graduate rate). The Certified Teacher Rate for Aiken, Beaufort, and Upstate is $362.25 for resident students per hour and $413.00 for nonresident students per hour. The Certified Teacher rate applies to regular graduate courses only and not to any program with a separate program or credit hour fee. Fee applies to part time students only. Supervisory Teacher Rate is $5 per credit hour for non-Columbia campuses and $50 per credit hour for Columbia campus. Professional Development contract courses ranging from $4,000 to $12,000 per course based on maximum of 25 students; additional students beyond 25 may enroll for a fee prorated from the base fee. The Chief Financial Officer must approve contract course amounts in advance. Fee assessed only for non-degree seeking students. Any special course fees to cover materials, travel, or other special costs above normal tuition must be approved in advance by the Provost. Special OSP courses assessed at Board mandated fee rate. Students must pay all fees directly to the University of South Carolina. The Chief Financial Officer must specifically approve any exceptions in advance. Nonresident students in study abroad programs are eligible for an in-state tuition waiver as provided in the South Carolina Code of Laws 59-112-70.All specially priced courses for Global Classrooms must be approved in advance by the Provost and the Chief Financial Officer (CFO). The High School Drama Conservatory is a three-week immersive theatre experience. The residential student is housed in a University dormitory, night and weekend activities and all meals are provided.", 'There may be a delay until the interview is complete or until class enrollment is finalized. Please direct any errors or issues to piano@mozart.sc.edu . Payments and refunds Tuition is billed every semester (Fall and Spring terms) and payment is due prior to the start of classes; see program-specific tuition rates. Payment can be made by the semester, or payments can be made in 3 installments per semester. Invoices are sent via email. Please pay correct amounts; requests for a current invoice can be submitted to piano@mozart.sc.edu . Any overpayment is applied to future tuition charges or refunded, less credit card fees. See Summer Piano page for costs of summer programs. Overdue accounts are assessed a $10 late fee ten (10) days after the due date. Tuition must be paid in full to participate in end-of-semester recitals. If a full refund is requested before the term begins, the refund is written for the amount paid minus a $30 processing fee. Refunds may be made by university check and this can take several weeks. Tuition is billed by semester and is due prior to the start of classes. If the multiple payment plan is chosen, tuition payments are due on the dates listed below. For your convenience, email invoices are sent prior to each due date. Fall Semester Spring Semester Prior to first lesson / class in August / September Prior to first lesson / class in January October 1 March 1 November 1 April 1 Discounts A $15 discount is available for senior citizens and USC faculty and staff for most programs above, except for Recreational Music Making and programs for USC students, which are already discounted. For families with more than one student enrolled in the Center, a $15 discount is available for each student enrollment. Discounts are applied to the first payment of each semester. Only one discount is accepted per enrollment. A limited amount of need-based scholarships are available; contact Dr.', 'Tuition and Fees | MUSC Skip to content Education Student Life Enrollment Management Bulletin Tuition and Fees Bulletin Request Program Information(https://redcap.musc.edu/surveys/?s=EFHN8PTNDWXLRFFN) Tuition and Fees 2024-2025 Tuition and Fees(https://education.musc.edu/students/enrollment/bulletin/tuition-and-fees/2024-to-2025) 2023-2024 Tuition and Fees(https://education.musc.edu/students/enrollment/bulletin/tuition-and-fees/2023-to-2024) Academic charges are established by the Board of Trustees. Circumstances beyond the control of the University may require adjustment of these published charges without notice.']
response: Tuition and fees are due before the start of classes each semester. Specific due dates for the Fall and Spring terms can be found in the context provided. For your convenience, email invoices are sent prior to each due date. If you choose the multiple payment plan, tuition payments are due on the specified dates listed in the context. Keep in mind that there is a $10 late fee assessed if payment is not made within ten days after the due date.
reference: Tuition deadlines are set by the Bursar’s Office. You are responsible for monitoring important dates and paying your tuition bill on time. Failure to pay your bill on time may result in being dropped from your classes.

user_input: How do I re-enroll in a course from which I have been dropped?
retrieved_contexts: ['If a student is dropped for non-payment and re-enrolls in classes after the payment deadline, these students and any students registering for the first time will need to pay their account balance in full or enroll in the University’s payment plan option by the drop/add date to retain their class schedule. Students who have been dropped for non-payment who request to be re-enrolled in their classes AFTER the last day to drop/add must submit a Registration Exception Form (AS-199)(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/registrar/forms/index.php) and will be assessed a $75 reinstatement fee. Late Registration: you can register yourself during the drop/add period.', "Once approved, the form can be submitted to the Registrar’s Office for processing. Reinstatement Fee A $75 reinstatement fee will be charged to your account if you re-enroll after the drop/add period. To avoid being dropped again, payment is required within 24 hours of being re-enrolled in your courses. Withdrawal and Refund Dates Withdrawing from class can have both an academic and financial impact. For information regarding academic withdrawal, please review the withdrawal information provided by the University Registrar(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/registrar/registration/withdrawal/index.php) . You can also v iew the Parts of Term Dates and Deadlines located in my.sc.edu(https://my.sc.edu/codes/partofterms/index) . Review important payment dates and deadlines » Late Registration You can register yourself during the drop/add period. After that period, you will be required to submit a Registration Exception Form to the Bursar’s Office for registration approval. This form can be found on the University Registrar’s website(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/registrar/registration/withdrawal/index.php) under Forms. Once approved, the form can be submitted to the Registrar’s Office for processing. If your late registration results in additional charges, you must make your payment or enroll in the payment plan within 24 hours of being added to the class. The Bursar's Office Our dedicated customer service team is available during normal business hours: 1244 Blossom Street - Suite 128(https://www.sc.edu/visit/map/index.php?id=744#!m/223349) Columbia, SC 29208 Phone: 803-777-4233 Fax: 803-777-7953 Email: bursar@mailbox.sc.edu Open Monday to Friday from 8:30 a.m. - 5 p.m.", "(http://my.sc.edu) Click on the Student tab then the Registration tile. Click Register for Classes and choose the term from which you want to withdraw. Registered classes are listed in the summary window in the lower right corner. Each should have an action drop down list. When the drop down is clicked, a student can select the 'Drop/Withdrawal Course/W' option. Please note: if the WF period has begun, the option would read 'Drop/Withdrawal Course/WF'. Click submit to complete the action. If you are not able to withdraw, it is possible that there is a hold on your account. Go back to the home screen, and click the 'Registration Notices and Holds' option to view holds or notices on your account. Contact the department(s) listed to have the hold removed. Once you are no longer enrolled in courses and all financial ties to the institution are taken care of, you are considered withdrawn. Please note that students typically do not become inactive until they miss a major semester (fall/spring) without a record of enrollment. If you are still receiving communication, please contact the department listed on the communication or unsubscribe from the listserv if given the option. Leaving or Transferring from USC If you are leaving USC after a full semester, follow the steps below: Don’t register for courses for the next semester. Speak with the Office of Financial Aid and Scholarships(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/financial_aid/index.php) if you receive scholarships, loans, or grants and you plan to attend USC in the near future. Resolve any financial debt or other obligations with campus departments (Housing, etc). If you are an international student, please contact International Student Services at 803-777-7461. Many transfer questions can be answered by the admissions office at your new school for transfer guidelines (including financial aid). You can obtain a copy of your USC transcript(http://my.sc.edu) via Self-Service Carolina. If you are leaving during a semester, please refer to the information above. If you are leaving USC but not transferring, the information above still applies. However, if you have additional questions, contact us at withdrawal@sc.edu . Please note: If you miss an entire semester, and wish to return, you will have to reapply to USC. Returning from Withdrawal If you miss a full semester (fall or spring) of enrollment at USC, to attend courses again, you must reapply to South Carolina by submitting an application for readmission(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_admissions/apply/index.php) . If you have a course grade or a “W” on your transcript for a previous semester (fall or spring), please contact your assigned academic advisor about registering for next semester courses. Hardship Withdrawal If you are withdrawing from the current semester during the withdraw fail period(https://my.sc.edu/codes/partofterms/index) due to a hardship (defined as a serious mental health, medical, or significant personal emergency which prevented you from successfully completing the semester), you may consider submitting a Hardship Withdrawal petition. Read more about hardship withdrawals , the petition process and other items to consider before withdrawing. Challenge the conventional.", 'Select Register for Classes 4. Select the appropriate term for class you want to drop 5. Select Drop/Withdrawal from the “Action” drop down menu on the bottom right of the screen I am not able to drop/add a class because of log in issues or a hold (ie. immunization, alcohol edu). What should I do? If you are unable to drop/add a class due to log in issues, please visit the Division of Information Technology’s website(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/division_of_information_technology/end_user_services/index.php) or call 803-777-1800. If you are unable to drop/add a class due to a hold, please view this list of common holds and restrictions that prevent the ability to drop/add courses . Does dropping a class affect scholarships or financial aid? It can. If you have any scholarships or financial aid, please contact the Office of Financial Aid before dropping/withdrawing from a course by visiting their website(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/financial_aid/index.php) or calling 803-777-8134. Does dropping a class affect progression in my major or my time to graduation? Depending on the class, it can. Please contact your primary academic advisor before dropping a class to discuss possible implications on progression in your major. Can I just the lab be dropped and keep the lecture or vice versa? Certain lecture courses and their labs are co-requisites and can only be added/dropped together. If you want to register for the lecture only or lab only and receive an error message, please contact the department of that course. Survey for students not returning to USC If you are not returning to USC in the following semester, please complete this brief survey sharing your reason(s) for not returning. We appreciate your feedback.', "Dropping Courses - Student Affairs and Academic Support | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Student Affairs and Academic Support SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Student Affairs and Academic Support Our Experts Our Offices Dean of Students Withdrawal Dropping Courses Dropping Courses There may be a time during your enrollment at the University of South Carolina when you consider dropping one or more of your courses. This section helps you consider all academic, financial, and other implications that you should know before withdrawing from a courses. Withdrawal Periods Withdrawals are defined by the time in the semester you wish to withdraw. There are both academic and financial implications associated with the date you drop your course(s). Hardship Withdrawals (defined as medical, mental health, or special circumstance) are only considered for past semesters or the current semester’s WF period. Prior to withdrawing, you are encouraged to contact the University Registrar(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/registrar/registration/withdrawal/index.php) to confirm the point in the semester for which you are withdrawing, and speak with a counselor at the Office of Financial Aid and Scholarships(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/financial_aid/index.php) for questions regarding how dropping some or all your courses will impact your aid (e.g. federal and private loans, grants, scholarships, special status, etc.). For information about tuition refunds, please contact the Bursar’s Office(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/bursar/refunds/index.php) . Dropping One or More Courses If you are dropping one or more of your courses, but not all your courses during the current semester: Visit the Registrar’s calendar(https://my.sc.edu/codes/partofterms/index) to know the withdrawal period in the semester for which you are dropping your courses.
